stem: A 16-year-old client with sickle cell anemia is hospitalized for a pain crisis. On Day 2, they develop a cough and chest pain. Based on the documentation in the Respiratory Tracking & Infiltrate Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute respiratory decompensation during hospitalization.
Background: HbSS. Admitted for vaso-occlusive crisis.
Assessment: Client has a new-onset fever and is tachypneic. Reporting sharp, pleuritic chest pain.
Recommendation: Chest X-ray and intensified pulmonary hygiene.

tabs.title: Respiratory Tracking & Infiltrate Log
tabs.content:
AssessmentFindingSignificance
Chest X-rayNew bilateral lower lobe infiltratesConfirms Diagnosis
Fever102.1°F (38.9°C)Inflammatory/Infectious
SputumNone producedNon-productive
RetractionsIntercostal/Subcostal presentIncreased work of breathing

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 110/64, HR 118, RR 32, SpO2 86% on RA (Previously 98%).

actionOptions.text: Encourage and assist with intensive Incentive Spirometry (10 times/hr)
Administer IV antibiotics and O2 as prescribed
Apply tight abdominal binders to reduce breathing effort
Withhold fluids to prevent pulmonary edema

parameterOptions.text: Respiratory rate and continuous pulse oximetry
Breath sounds and presence of pleuritic chest pain
Daily measurement of fasting blood glucose

rationale.correct: This is Acute Chest Syndrome (ACS) (c2), the leading cause of death in sickle cell patients. ACS is defined by a new infiltrate on CXR plus fever, cough, OR chest pain. The client's sudden drop in SpO2 (86%) and new fever (102.1°F) are classic cues. Priority actions are intensive pulmonary hygiene with incentive spirometry (a1) to prevent further lung collapse/sickling and antibiotics/oxygen (a2). Key parameters: Respiratory stability (p1) and lung assessment (p2).
clinicalPearls: ACS can be caused by infection, fat embolism, or pulmonary sickling.
Incentive spirometry is the most effective NURSING intervention to prevent/treat ACS once a patient has a pain crisis.
The goal is to keep the SpO2 > 94%.

questionTrap.trap: Treating this as 'just pneumonia' and missing the incentive spirometry component.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While antibiotics are given, the MECHANICAL expansion of the lungs is what stops the 'sickling' in the pulmonary capillaries. Incentive spirometry is the NGN priority for SCD respiratory issues.

mnemonic.title: ACS Danger
mnemonic.expansion: A-Acute SpO2 drop. C-Chest pain/Cough. S-Spirometry (Push it!).
